Scenario: Your best friend, Jenna, just messaged you asking what's up. This is the third message she has sent this week, but you ignored the first two. You:
A. Avoid looking at your phone because the notification fills you with anxiety for ignoring her. She's your best friend, but your depression has left you uninterested in doing anything.
C. Respond, apologizing for missing the earlier messages because of how unmotivated you've been to do anything.
B. Respond, apologizing for missing the earlier messages because of how busy you've been.
D. Immediately call her and tell her how excited you are to hang out this weekend.
Answer:

Scenario: Your pet guinea pig dies. You:
A. Didn't even notice until the smell of its dead body starts to overwhelm your room.
B. Are surprised by how apathetic you are in response to this.
C. Write a song lamenting the loss of your beloved pet, and upload it to youtube.
D. Write a heartfelt facebook post featuring your favorite pictures of him.
Answer:

Scenario: It is the end of the school year, and the week has finally come for AP testing. You:
A. Are so demotivated and lacking in concentration during the first test that you only finish a quarter of the questions.
B. Are filled with anxiety at the thought of testing exposing your lack of motivation the past year in school.
C. Spend your last few nights cramming material with your friends, and miraculously pull off a decent score.
D. Do the best you can, and are pleased with your performance on the free-response questions.
Answer:

Scenario: You have a presentation on behalf of your boss to the company board next week. You:
A. Procrastinate until an hour before the presentation, at which point you scramble together a few slides.
B. Procrastinate due to anxiety until the night before, then stay up the entire night preparing.
C. Practice speaking to your coworkers in preparation.
D. Look forward to this opportunity to show off your hard work and perhaps even receive a promotion.
Answer:

Scenario: Your friend offers to help you find a therapist. You:
A. Burst into tears at the thought of how much of a failure you must seem like to your friend.
B. Agree that it's probably a good idea, but are worried about seeming like a failure to them.
C. Appreciate the sentiment, but have already tried and did not find it helpful.
D. Are interested and ask her what her experience has been with it.
Answer:

Scenario: Your mother died a year ago. Friday night, you start missing her especially severely. You:
A. Get so down on yourself that you contemplate suicide.
B. Spend the weekend back on a bender lamenting how little you've accomplished since then.
C. Stay at home tonight and listen to music while looking at old photos.
D. Call your dad and talk to him to cheer yourself up.
Answer:

Scenario: In a creative writing class, the teacher tells you to write a story that is a metaphor that reflects the ups and downs of your life over the past year. You:
A. Are embarrassed at the thought of what an honest account would look like to others.
B. Write a recurring fantasy you've had involving a spider with knives that cuts your body to small pieces and sends them floating down a river.
C. Write a story about a whale that befriends a human and helps him escape society.
D. Write a Rocky-style story of hard work overcoming adversity.
Answer:

Scenario: In philosophy class, the professor leads an ice-breaking session by having students discuss the oldest of all philosophy questions: what's the meaning of life? Reflecting, you think:
A. Whatever the meaning of life is, I'm pretty sure I'm not experiencing it right now. Life sucks.
B. Who said life has meaning? Recently, it has been pretty meaningless in every way.
C. Humans have evolved to reproduce and survive, the rest is fluff.
D. How can there be an answer to this question?
Answer:

D. You're most creative in the mornings, when you have nothing else to do.
